main_definition: A township is a subdivision of a county or region, typically used to describe an area with its own local government, usually found in rural areas.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Local administrative division within a state or country
meanings_and_examples.example: In New Jersey, the United States, townships are one of the forms of incorporated municipalities.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A small rural community with its own local government and services
meanings_and_examples.example: The residents of Springtown Township gather for their annual festival to celebrate community spirit.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A geographic subdivision used in some countries, particularly in Africa and Asia, that may have a different administrative role or function
meanings_and_examples.example: In South Africa, townships historically refer to areas where non-white residents were forced to live during the apartheid era.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A term used by some Indigenous peoples in North America for their self-governing territories
meanings_and_examples.example: The Haudenosaunee Confederacy, also known as the Iroquois League or Six Nations, consists of towns that are similar to townships.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A former name used in some countries for a local administrative unit before modern reforms
meanings_and_examples.example: The term 'township' was widely used across many parts of the United Kingdom until recent decades, where it has been replaced by various other terms.
